statement.p: Graph the equation \displaystyle{y}={2}{\left({4}^{{{x}+{4}}}\right)}+{5}. You will select a point on the asymptote (only y coordinate matters); then you select two points on the exponential.

solution.p: Because \displaystyle{y}={2}{\left({4}^{{{x}+{4}}}\right)}+{5} has \displaystyle+{5} at the end, the asymptote is at \displaystyle{y}={5}.
One convenient point is where \displaystyle{x}+{4}={0} which is \displaystyle{x}=-{4}. Here \displaystyle{y}={7}.
A second convenient point is one right of -4, which is \displaystyle{x}=-{3}. Here \displaystyle{y}={13}
